data.title: CrossFit MINS Workout
data.text: Workout of the Day 14.10.2025 WOD1.Front Squat On the 1:45 x 6 6-5-4-3-2-1 Front Squats *start at 50-60% and build to 90% of 1 RM 2.Conditioning On the 1:30 x 12 Intervals 1: X Calories Row 2: 15 Front Squat 3: X Toes to Bar Sweat: 19/14 Cal.; 40/20; 20 Knee / Straight Leg Raises Train: 22/17 Cal.; 55/35; 15 Toes to Bar Compete: 25/20 Cal. ; 70/50; 20 Toes to Bar
data.full_text:
Workout of the Day

14.10.2025

WOD
1.Front Squat
On the 1:45 x 6
6-5-4-3-2-1 Front Squats
*start at 50-60% and build to 90% of 1 RM



2.Conditioning
On the 1:30 x 12 Intervals
1: X Calories Row
2: 15 Front Squat
3: X Toes to Bar



Sweat: 19/14 Cal.; 40/20; 20 Knee / Straight Leg Raises
Train: 22/17 Cal.; 55/35; 15 Toes to Bar
Compete: 25/20 Cal. ; 70/50; 20 Toes to Bar

ai_explanation.explanation:
Workout Overview


Hey everyone! Todayâ€™s WOD is a fantastic blend of strength and conditioning thatâ€™s going to challenge your legs, core, and cardiovascular endurance. Weâ€™ll kick things off with a strength segment focusing on Front Squats, where weâ€™ll progressively build up to a heavy single. Then, weâ€™ll dive into a conditioning piece that includes rowing, front squats, and toes to bar, designed to test your stamina and grit. Letâ€™s break it down step by step!


---


Strength Segment


Front Squat

**Overview:**

The Front Squat is a key movement that emphasizes leg strength, core stability, and proper squat mechanics. Itâ€™s crucial to maintain good form to prevent injury and maximize effectiveness.


Technique Steps:
  • **Setup**: Start by placing the barbell on your front rack position. This means resting it on your shoulders with your elbows high and your hands gripping the bar.
  • **Feet Position**: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly pointed out.
  • **Engage Core**: Take a deep breath, brace your core, and keep your chest up.
  • **Descent**: Initiate the squat by bending at the knees and hips simultaneously. Keep your elbows high and your torso upright as you lower down.
  • **Depth**: Aim to get your thighs parallel to the ground or lower, while keeping your heels flat on the floor.
  • **Ascent**: Push through your heels to stand back up, driving your knees out and maintaining that upright torso.

    • Form Tips:
  • Keep your elbows high throughout the movement to prevent the bar from rolling forward.
  • Focus on keeping your weight in your heels and your chest up to maintain balance.
  • Use a mirror or ask a coach for feedback on your form.

    • Scaling/Modifications:
  • If youâ€™re new to this movement, consider using a lighter barbell or even a PVC pipe to practice the mechanics.
  • You can also perform Front Squats with a kettlebell or dumbbell held in the goblet position.

    • Loading:
  • **Sweat**: Start at 50-60% of your 1RM.
  • **Train**: Build up to 70-80% of your 1RM.
  • **Compete**: Aim for 90% of your 1RM.

    • ---


    Conditioning Segment [12 Intervals on the 1:30]


    1. Row for Calories

    **Overview:**

    Rowing is a great way to build aerobic capacity and engage multiple muscle groups. The goal here is to accumulate calories efficiently.


    Technique Steps:
  • **Setup**: Sit on the rower with your feet secured in the straps.
  • **Grip**: Hold the handle with both hands, palms facing down.
  • **Drive**: Start with your legs, pushing through your heels while leaning back slightly and pulling the handle towards your chest.
  • **Recovery**: Extend your arms, lean forward, and bend your knees to return to the starting position.

    • Form Tips:
  • Keep your back straight and avoid hunching over.
  • Use your legs to drive the power, not just your arms.

    • Scaling/Modifications:
  • Adjust the damper setting on the rower to make it easier or harder.
  • If rowing isnâ€™t an option, you can substitute with a bike or run.

    • Loading:
  • **Sweat**: 19/14 Calories
  • **Train**: 22/17 Calories
  • **Compete**: 25/20 Calories

    • ---


    2. Front Squats (15 Reps)

    **Overview:**

    This is a repeat of the strength segment but in a conditioning context. Youâ€™ll be moving quickly, so focus on maintaining form under fatigue.


    Technique Steps:
  • Follow the same steps as outlined in the strength segment.

    • Scaling/Modifications:
  • Use a lighter weight if youâ€™re feeling fatigued or if your form starts to break down.

    • ---


    3. Toes to Bar

    **Overview:**

    Toes to bar is a fantastic core exercise that also engages your shoulders and grip. Itâ€™s important to maintain control throughout the movement.


    Technique Steps:
  • **Hang Position**: Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended.
  • **Engage Core**: Activate your core and pull your legs up towards the bar.
  • **Lift**: As you lift your legs, aim to touch your toes to the bar while keeping your body controlled.
  • **Lower**: Slowly lower your legs back to the starting position.

    • Form Tips:
  • Keep your shoulders engaged and avoid swinging.
  • Use a kipping motion if youâ€™re comfortable, but focus on control.

    • Scaling/Modifications:
  • If toes to bar is too challenging, you can scale to knee raises or straight leg raises.

    • Loading:
  • **Sweat**: 20 Knee / Straight Leg Raises
  • **Train**: 15 Toes to Bar
  • **Compete**: 20 Toes to Bar

    • ---


    Strategy Advice


  • **Pacing**: For the rowing, find a steady pace that you can maintain throughout the intervals. Donâ€™t go all out on the first round; save some energy for the later rounds.
  • **Breaking Up Sets**: For the front squats, consider breaking them into smaller sets if needed (e.g., 8-7 or 5-5-5) to maintain form.
  • **Core Control**: On the toes to bar, focus on controlled movements rather than speed to avoid swinging.

    • ---


    Thatâ€™s it, team! Remember to listen to your body, focus on your form, and have fun with it. Letâ€™s get after it today! ðŸ’ª

combined_content.workout_text:
WOD:


  • Front Squat
  • On the 1:45 x 6
  • 6-5-4-3-2-1 Front Squats
  • *Start at 50-60% and build to 90% of 1 RM

  • Conditioning
  • On the 1:30 x 12 Intervals

    • 1: X Calories Row

    2: 15 Front Squats

    3: X Toes to Bar


    Sweat: 19/14 Cal.; 40/20; 20 Knee / Straight Leg Raises

    Train: 22/17 Cal.; 55/35; 15 Toes to Bar

    Compete: 25/20 Cal.; 70/50; 20 Toes to Bar

Front Squats (15 Reps) **Overview:** This is a repeat of the strength segment but in a conditioning context. Youâ€™ll be moving quickly, so focus on maintaining form under fatigue. #### Technique Steps: - Follow the same steps as outlined in the strength segment. #### Scaling/Modifications: - Use a lighter weight if youâ€™re feeling fatigued or if your form starts to break down. --- ### 3. Itâ€™s important to maintain control throughout the movement. #### Technique Steps: 1. **Hang Position**: Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended. 2. **Engage Core**: Activate your core and pull your legs up towards the bar. 3. **Lift**: As you lift your legs, aim to touch your toes to the bar while keeping your body controlled. 4. **Lower**: Slowly lower your legs back to the starting position. #### Form Tips: - Keep your shoulders engaged and avoid swinging. - Use a kipping motion if youâ€™re comfortable, but focus on control. #### Scaling/Modifications: - If toes to bar is too challenging, you can scale to knee raises or straight leg raises. #### Loading: - **Sweat**: 20 Knee / Straight Leg Raises - **Train**: 15 Toes to Bar - **Compete**: 20 Toes to Bar --- ## Strategy Advice - **Pacing**: For the rowing, find a steady pace that you can maintain throughout the intervals. Remember to listen to your body, focus on your form, and have fun with it. Letâ€™s get after it today! ðŸ’ª
